28.94.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain, coming to
you this week from the People's Republic of

33.82.text:
Coming up: This is where the pheasant and
the muntjac come from, and I'll be looking

40.06.text:
I'll be visiting one of the factories in Cina
that make all the kit we use to attract pigeons

46.87.text:
First, I'm going to this paradise island to
look for deer, goats and rabbits

54.21.text:
So here's the story. In 2011, we carry a news
report saying that the first man in China

59.86.text:
to own land is a petrochemicals millionaire
who has bought a lease on an island near the

64.14.text:
city of Ningbo where, instead of opening a
casino or a shopping centre, he opens a hunting

69.49.text:
reserve, and this in a country where it is
widely believed that hunting is banned. Well,

76.06.text:
Erik van der Horst gets in touch with us to
say he is based in Ningbo and would we like

80.89.text:
to go? I push in front of David, Roy, Mark,
Crow, Dom and everyone else, and say yes please.

82.36.text:
18 months later, I am at a ferry terminal
that may not be up to much but the boat itself

89.56.text:
So we've left the Chinese mainland behind
us and we are heading for we don't know what.

100.78.text:
But this is the birthplace of Chinese hunting
- something that's been banned along with

106.03.text:
guns since 1949. Here, it's not only tolerated
it's quite possibly legal. Let's find out.

110.70.text:
It's a half-hour air-conditioned whiz over
the water past dazzling James Bond scenery.

117.14.text:
We come into port and, if you listen carefully,
you can hear them say it: "The plane, boss,

121.81.text:
the plane". We land, we round a corner and
there is the hotel.

128.95.text:
The following morning, we are up early to
go stalking. Rosy-fingered dawn is spectacular.

134.00.text:
The potential for hunting less so. Erik spots
a herd of goats or, as he disparagingly calls

140.13.text:
I reckon we will have about three to four
hour stalk up to the sheep you just filmed.

147.00.text:
By the sounds of it we have got quite an experience
and quite a good stalk. As far as I understand

154.48.text:
we will call in the sheep when we get near.
It will be something like "sheep, sheep, sheep,

162.36.text:
sheep" at which point they will all come running
in and we have got about ten minutes to shoot

173.79.text:
The gamekeeper hands out the firearms to Erik
me and to Mr Yang, a Chinese industrialist.

178.80.text:
The 12-bore shotguns are marked with the word
Ying - there: Yang with Ying - though it's

184.23.text:
hard to know if Ying is the make of the gun
or its dynasty.

188.10.text:
We will use three-shot cartridges, whatever
we are shooting at: deer, goats, rabbits or

193.78.text:
pheasants. It is indeed a long walk in to
the goats. There is plenty of sign of muntjac

198.46.text:
but the undergrowth is so thick, you would
have to be a muntjac to get close to them.

203.48.text:
We reach the farm animals. Erik and the gamekeeper
stalk forward. The goats turn out to be too

208.85.text:
quick for Erik. Maybe this is not going to
be easy after all. And Erik is cross about

213.82.text:
another gap between European and Chinese hunting
cultures.

216.75.text:
It is a great and interesting stalk, but I
am not going to shoot a goat at 50 metres

221.99.text:
or more with a shotgun. We will give it to
our Chinese friend

229.93.text:
Another complaint Erik has is the speed at
which the Chinese stalk

233.28.text: Fastest stalk I've ever done in my life

235.86.text:
When I take over the gun, I slow the pace
down significantly.

240.15.text:
However, apart from the bark of deer and the
occasionally crashing noise, I see nothing.

245.53.text:
By 9am, the temperature has reached 30 degrees
centigrade and the game is lying doggo, but

250.72.text:
at least the gamekeeper is keeping something
- his sense of humour. We head for the hotel,

255.44.text:
where I ask Mr Yang what he thinks of the
morning.

258.08.text:
He says there are 
not too much game in this island.

268.46.text:
Here the hunting is forbidden at night. But
if we go out at night we may hunt some deers.

274.88.text:
I also want to know what the Chinese think
of shooting and hunting - and do they enjoy

279.75.text:
He says in China people are only hunting on
islands, Gobi Desert and forests.

291.65.text:
Ok and what kind of animals do they hunt in
China?

303.39.text:
In northern part of China and eastern China,
people hunt bears, and in Mongolia people

313.15.text:
And for him is it about the hunting or eating
the food afterwards or the whole thing. That

324.34.text: is important for us to understand.

337.86.text:
People go hunting just for fun and you know
that guns are illegal in China, so people

347.90.text:
who are interested in them just due to their
interest.

352.49.text:
Throughout our trip to China, we were unable
to find out whether hunting is really banned.

357.09.text:
Certainly, gun ownership carries a stiff prison
sentence in some provinces, but plenty of

362.05.text:
people own guns, and some we met own them
with the permission of the police. Look at

366.18.text:
the London 2012 Olympics. The Chinese won
more medals in the shooting events than any

372.24.text:
As you can imagine, Erik has strong views
about the hunting - and about what he would

377.98.text: do if he were running the gaff.

379.92.text:
At the end of our walk I actually had the
feeling that what we did may actually have

386.78.text:
been wrong for the Chinese way. So what they
do is they walk so fast and basically they

395.67.text:
Where we now had to compromise with too many
people and of course the stalker behind us

405.49.text:
Yes, and I noticed that if we stopped where
we might have seen a muntjac that was a good

410.22.text:
opportunity to have a cigarette, especially
if the wind was behind us.

415.54.text:
Interesting yes. And of course the misfires
with the shotgun were absolutely ... you have

420.45.text:
to cope with a lot. But we are sitting at
one end of this beautiful beach, it is not

429.08.text:
Actually I think it is a really, really good
place. The sea with the beach. The hotel is

434.07.text:
sunny and comfortable. I love the food it
is really excellent food.

439.33.text:
I love the fact that you eat what you shoot
immediately.

443.57.text:
And to be honest if they would buy two dogs
and a buttalo call

448.83.text: That would make all the difference.

452.31.text:
Absolutely. Actually I think it could be a

458.12.text:
people with the bunnies and the goats and
on the other for Western people who have more

466.14.text:
stalking experience, but they need to learn
a lot.

469.62.text: They need to learn about muntjac stalking.

471.55.text: Shall we go back in for a cheeky rice wine?

474.65.text: Um that might be a very good idea.

477.03.text: And perhaps take a surf later.

480.05.text:
Late afternoon before dinner we head off again,
this time after bunnies which we have seen

484.20.text:
near the hotel and look suspiciously un-nervous.
Our new Chinese friend limbers up by practicing

491.22.text:
on a nearby flag pole. It is only a few yards
and we come upon a rabbit. Another 20 yards

497.15.text:
and blow me another rabbit lurking behind
some rushes, but otherwise oblivious to our

501.93.text:
presence. Erik shoots, misses then goes to
see if he can flush it out.

506.75.text: It is wild enough to have gone into hiding.

509.98.text:
Further up the path, it's my turn to shoot
and bring down another mighty rabbit.

513.79.text:
Well I can't show you too much, but two man
team from Europe is one all versus China at

519.99.text:
As well as the rabbits, the island offers
Chinese bayberries.

525.87.text:
With the scores running even, Mr Yang edges
ahead with first one rabbit, and then another

530.19.text:
- but after we have one each, Erik and I are
not quite so keen on the sporting side of

539.02.text:
The Chinese may have a lot to learn from us
about shooting - but we have plenty to learn

543.07.text:
from them about eating. Everything we shot
or caught on our trip we ate immediately,

547.93.text:
meat, feet, guts, backbone and all - and I
might have come home smelling like a Chinese

556.36.text:
Food for the Chinese is a social event that
takes place three times a day. Whenever possible,

560.47.text:
it involves beer, rice wine and French brandy.
Here's Mr Yang showing his skills as a calligrapher,

565.99.text:
writing Fieldsports Channel in Chinese - literally
"hunting the weird". If the hordes sweep in

572.20.text: from the East, this is our new logo.

575.17.text:
Then Mr Yang, partly fuelled by rice wine,
shows how he will disable Erik when that day

581.51.text:
The Golden Sand Bay Hunting Resort is expensive,
but much of the cost is tied up in the price

588.11.text:
for hiring the boat. One night there comes
to �200 a person, including ferry, bed,

593.65.text:
board and two outings shooting. Also, the
price goes up significantly once the manager

597.85.text:
decides you are rich. If you want to find
out more and you either speak Mandarin or

602.33.text:
you don't mind Google Translate's version,

Another hunting resort advertising in China
is the Oriental International Hunting Park

611.32.text:
in Shanxi province, west of Beijing. Visit
East-Hunt.com

618.53.text: Do you think shoot it anyway?

622.87.text:
Ok and now it's over to David on the Fieldsports
Channel news stump.

636.80.text:
The Netherlands has 300,000 greylag geese.
The environment department of a Dutch university

643.52.text:
says that 380,000 geese need to be gassed
over the next five years to bring that number

648.93.text:
down to 100,000. It costs around 18 euros
to gas each goose. Holland banned goose shooting

659.26.text:
Our government says well when you hunt them
the next problem you are going to have is

662.93.text:
what are you going to do with those animals
and that is more or less one of the reasons

667.70.text:
that I wrote a book about it. How do you get
it back in the food circuit.

672.31.text:
And you can watch more of that interview by
clicking on the link.

675.36.text:
Now, Swiss MPs have voted against a ban on
stray cat shooting. They rejected a motion

681.56.text:
to outlaw the cat hunt. The Swiss Government
says there are around 1.5 million stray cats

687.00.text:
in Switzerland and it points to a British
study which shows that cats kill 15 birds

694.39.text:
Staying with cats. A woman from Indiana in
the USA who shot what she thought was a bobcat

699.91.text:
that had been attacking her own cats was surprised
when it turned out to be a leopard. The owner

705.79.text:
of a local wildlife rescue centre that specialises
in big cats denies that it is his.

711.70.text:
If you would prefer to see a live leopard
instead of a dead one, then click on the link,

716.59.text:
to see our how to release a leopard film.
Made all the better because Charlie nearly

722.45.text:
Our own Roy Lupton has been appearing on ITV
news this week. Roy was talking about the

727.50.text:
urban fox problem after ITV Meridian used
our night vision footage of urban fox calling

733.52.text:
in Maidstone town centre. The report also
featured a fox expert who suggested that walking

739.71.text:
a dog around the edge of your garden will
keep foxes at bay. Yeah right.

746.25.text:
Schools Challenge TV is offering a competition
prize this week. You can win a family ticket

751.10.text:
to the CLA Game Fair. Click on the link on
the screen to watch this week's show, which

755.40.text:
says how Schools Challenge Academy members
plan to take their shooting careers to the

759.03.text: next level and bid for Olympic success.

762.89.text:
And finally, these South African tourists
got a surprise when an angry giraffe started

768.02.text:
chasing them. Giraffes can run up to 35 miles
per hour and have a lethal kick.

774.83.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

786.77.text:
Thank you David, very Oriental. Now the good
news is I got him. Later in the programme

791.89.text:
we are going to do some real poaching in China.
First, duck, Peking duck? Crispy fried duck?

797.80.text:
No, decoy duck, because China is where they
are all made.

800.56.text:
It 
is hard to put into words how urban China
is becoming and in such a short time. Cities

811.40.text:
I have never heard of before such as Ningbo
and Guangzhou are already like a cross between

819.32.text:
So that racket in the background - this is
where your duck decoys come from. I'm here

824.18.text:
to meet Frank, who is going to tell me all
about it.

827.77.text:
I fly to Europe each year one time, two times
so I see the chain stores, I see the shops

844.20.text:
and I get some ideas from them and I come
back to China and make my lines for the hunting.

850.29.text: How many of these are you shipping every year?

854.43.text:
Half a million pieces, normally, totally,
together, like goose, crow, pigeon, magpie

863.99.text: That's goose, crow, pigeon, magpie and ducks

867.81.text:
It's not just deeks. Frank's company makes
float tubes for fishermen and even standalone

875.17.text:
It's all too much for keen deerstalker Erik.
He has to go and try it out. It's meant to

cope with one tonne of weight. However, Erik
may need to go easy on the wontons as he breaks

885.60.text:
the ladder on the way up - and has to use
the other highseat ladder to come down. Back

889.86.text: to the drawing board with that product.

892.30.text:
If you are planning to order around half a
million decoys and you want to find out more,

898.28.text:
Now from a beautiful beach resort to the high
hills of Canton where I will be going pheasant

910.46.text:
Picture a group of country blokes sitting
down to a good breakfast before going out

918.82.text:
for a bit of walked-up shooting. That's what
we have here. There is lots of chat about

923.87.text:
what we might see, what pheasants look like,
what eagle tastes like and that needless to

927.83.text: say we should have been here last week.

930.22.text:
How do Erik and I establish that we know how
to shoot a muntjac if we see one? We show

934.98.text: them films of Roy Lupton of course.

939.38.text:
They tell us they mainly shoot pheasants here.
But there is a variety of game. That is a

943.91.text:
leopard cat, which is common across China,
India and the rest of Asia, and is fond of

949.39.text:
In the 1950s, there were tigers here. Locals
say the government came and shot them all

954.31.text:
- but it is hard to see how. There is plenty
of game in the tangle of bamboo. The rural

960.20.text:
China you see is hacked out of thick undergrowth.
There's an awful lot of China you don't see.

969.21.text:
The guns our hunter friends use would not
pass muster at a British shoot. Outside, they

974.07.text:
proudly show off a heavily repaired Manufrance
No5 �Robust' shotgun and a single-barrel

979.66.text:
home made hammer gun, both of them 12-bore.Cartridges

986.61.text:
We load up into vehicles and head out into
the countryside.

994.56.text:
We're hunting here in Canton Province - and
these guys are out after meat, so we're turning

1001.56.text:
down the really little birds and going for
the bigger ones

1004.75.text:
At first, we drive round local farmland looking
for birds. When we see one, we stop the cars

1010.14.text:
and one of the two shooters hop out and have
a go. Any biggish bird will do - like this,

1014.62.text: a common bird in the rice padis, a brown crake.

1020.61.text:
Now, as you have probably noticed, they ask
us to blob-out their faces, and they are not

1027.98.text:
keen to be interviewed. I think they are unclear
about whether or not shooting is legal in

1032.49.text:
this province in the eyes of the police or
the Government. But if you do go shooting,

1040.15.text:
Unbelievable you would expect the farmers
to just show up with strange people running

1044.41.text:
all over their land. Especially us with the
camera and the dogs and everything and there

1051.23.text:
was absolutely no reply. Even if we passed
them they were just very friendly, a little

1053.99.text:
bit afraid of guns but it was really, really
positive.

1058.39.text:
At last we hit the trail of the bird we had
come to see - the pheasant, which of course

1063.45.text:
comes from here in China. The guys make their
way across the field and a volley of shots

1068.48.text:
follow our soon to be lunch.The dogs leave
the bird for our hunter to retrieve who is

1076.84.text:
very pleased with it. This pheasant ... is
nothing like a michigan blue, but a subtle

1083.22.text:
brown. It isn't going to matter what colour
it is in a few minutes. After that it is time

1091.65.text:
for me to have a go and I think there is a
50, 50 chance that I am going to the way of

1096.08.text:
that last pheasant. I hope the string and
ceiling wax will hold. Thankfully I am in

1104.22.text:
one piece as is the pheasant I have just shot
over. We both live to fight another day.

1109.72.text:
It was a very challenging shot there - didn't
you think?

1112.37.text:
Um I was watching it from the side and it
looked easy. Probably if you were standing

1117.58.text:
behind that very short side by side it probably
actually was very difficult.

1121.85.text:
I would like to come back here with a reliable
20 bore. A mixture of six shot and buck shot

1127.72.text:
cartridges in case of larger game a couple
of british gun dogs, a couple of books so

1132.06.text:
I can point out to the locals what I want
to shoot and a butterfly book so that I can

1135.61.text:
identify the dozens of fabulous insects that
I will see. I would like to spend a week walking

1141.13.text:
the paddy fields of China in among this gorgeous

1146.51.text:
would shoot this, he being both hysterical

1149.49.text:
First of all I think overcome certain taboos,
shooting muntjac with a shotgun, but also

1156.66.text:
some challenges you have to walk up much,
much closer for example to the muntjac to

1161.06.text:
be able to kill it. The rough shooting I found
very interesting. I think if you are doing

1166.46.text:
it in the right season, we saw a lot of tracks
of pheasants, of muntjacs and saw a lot of

1171.52.text:
quails. It could be really interesting for
rough shooting.

1176.66.text:
The quail are exactly what I would like to
shoot, but the locals consider them to be

1187.84.text:
The dogs are peculiar. They have an inscrutable
calm about them, but then suddenly burst into

1193.89.text:
But the dogs are not much good at retrieving
game, even with the encouragement of the shooters,

1198.04.text:
who regard any bird lost in that deep thicket
a personal failure

1203.42.text:
At last we stop at a collective farm for lunch
with the workers. This kind of generosity

1207.79.text:
is normal, charming, and it only costs a few
bob. The Chinese are very much in touch with

1214.27.text:
what they eat. In rural areas like this you
are woken each morning at 4am by the squeals

1219.43.text:
of whatever is on tonight's restaurant menus.
If you can turn up at a remote farmhouse with

1226.41.text:
We shoot a brace of crake, five pheasants
and a pigeon. We turn down several coveys

1230.62.text:
of quail. If anyone offers you walked-up shooting
in countryside like this, you have got to

1236.80.text:
Now for some bushcraft. It's the Chinese bayberry
season, known locally as yang-mei.

1247.65.text:
One thing Erik insists, as a European, you
can like the Chinese, laugh with them, eat

1252.96.text:
well with them but do not expect to understand
them.

1256.40.text:
Like every developed country in the world,
they have plenty of competing religions. The

1260.34.text:
main two in this area are Taoism, which gives
us yin, yang and several martial arts, and

1265.34.text:
Buddhism, which gives us Nirvana, and I don't
mean the one with Kurt Cobain.

1269.08.text:
I am off to pick berries in the woods with
the sunniest girl in China. Sunshine Sun.

1275.68.text:
And now this, this, this, this trees are our
family trees and you can enjoy it.

1299.89.text:
After the frantic few days of travelling around
the country hunting, bayberry picking - just

1304.11.text:
like blackberry picking - is gentle and therapeutic.
Sunshine is proud of her family trees and

1309.77.text:
passionate about the fruit, as are most people
in this part of the country. Everywhere you

1314.57.text:
go there are people balancing baskets over
their shoulders, carrying the fruit to market.

1319.56.text:
Once again, it's all about the food. I asked
if this had anything to do with the starvation

1323.96.text:
the Chinese went through under Chairman Mao.
Everyone said no - food has been a Chinese

1337.67.text: How many of the baskets do you get every year?

1346.64.text: How many baskets like this of fruit?

1351.71.text:
There are about 30 trees all owned by my family
on this hill, one hill. My family has two

1371.69.text: hills with young May trees. Sorry.

1377.52.text: Thank you Sunshine. Sorry to interrupt.

1380.15.text:
Chinese bayberries are called yang-mei and
where-every we go they are delicious, sweet

1384.79.text:
yet sour. Sweet and sour. Now there is an
idea.

1390.10.text:
Now we have shot birds, we have shot mammals
in China. The one thing that is missing is

1396.63.text:
If hunting and shooting is somewhere between
banned and reluctantly allowed, fishing is

1400.88.text:
a major national pastime. And once again it
comes down to food.

1405.82.text:
If you are getting a picture of a people who
like eating game, just wait till they get

1409.47.text:
their chopsticks and their chops around fish.
And when a restaurant advertises fresh fish,

1421.96.text:
I've come to meet Chen An. He's a factory
boss who likes nothing more than a morning

1426.35.text:
float fishing for carp. I meet him thanks
to his sister, Lily, who speaks English.

1431.49.text: What is the fish food made from?

1436.85.text:
Made from rice? And does it have flavour,
like meat flavour?

1454.26.text:
I want to ask Mr Chen if he gets first dibs
at the newest fishing equipment on the market,

1458.74.text:
because it all comes from China. But perhaps
he is a businessman first and a fisherman

1463.67.text:
second, because he reckons I want to make
a deal on 
a new rod.

1473.36.text:
If you want to buy fishing equipment he can
give you some information. The main factories

1480.62.text:
to produce this equipment are in Shandong
province.

1493.68.text:
Fishing is huge in China. Public parks in
Chinese cities have lakes and those lakes

1498.15.text:
have fishermen. These lads are fishing right
in the middle of Ningbo, population 5.7 million.

1504.14.text:
I ask Philip the translator to ask what they
are fishing for.

1515.83.text:
That will be crucian carp, then. Back at Mr
Chen's pond and the temperature has risen

1520.88.text:
to just short of 40 degrees centigrade - that's
over 100 degrees fahrenheit. You can see why

1526.57.text:
the Chinese like a sport that involves sitting
still, even though he gallantly gives up his

1530.59.text: seat in the shade to his sister.

1533.06.text:
Now it's Erik's turn to fish. The heat may
be dulling our mammalian senses but the carp

1539.25.text:
Nearly got one. It was a little bit quick
and my response wasn't fast enough. But in

1544.42.text: this hot weather it isn't easy.

1546.62.text:
Then it goes right for Erik and he is into
his first Chinese crucian.

1551.45.text:
Now it's my turn to get the wrong end of the
stick:

1555.42.text:
So he likes hunting, he likes the idea of
hunting but he can't go hunting because of

1561.80.text:
the current situation. Would he like to see
change?

1565.24.text:
He likes the hunting but the government closes
the hunting places from each April to October.

1580.10.text:
During this time you take your guns to the
police station.

1593.74.text:
This is a country of a billion+ people. Around
a quarter of the world's population is Chinese.

1599.90.text:
The government here tolerates fishing but
it says that hunting/shooting is banned. That's

1605.29.text:
not what I've found. Just look at the restaurant
menus. They go from pheasant through deer

1611.26.text:
and anything you can pull out of the water,
right up to whale meat, and I have to say

1614.18.text:
the jellyfish was rubbery. You don't need
a game meat marketing executive here because

1619.70.text:
everybody wants to eat everything. It's probably
a good thing that the Government doesn't encourage

1625.05.text:
hunting any more than it does, otherwise there'd
be nothing left. However, this is a country

1632.06.text:
Right. My go. Mr Chen sets me up and I get
to sit in Zen-like fisherman's trance, at

1638.61.text:
one with my float, feeling slow disintegration
of ball of rice on the sharp little hook.

1646.51.text:
Very unchinese feeling, but that is a really
wonderful moment. First Chinese carp.

1654.23.text:
It's been a glorious, sweltering day. With
a rod in your hand, you can forget the smog

1658.89.text:
and horror of life in urban China. And Mr
Chen has plenty of fish to give to his friends.

1664.57.text:
Of course, we don't have a monopoly on making
hunting films in China, even though we reckon

1670.11.text:
were probably the first. Let's have a look
at the rest of them on Hunting YouTube

1678.90.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting, shooting and fishing videos

1686.15.text:
El Dorado of Chinese hunting is the Mongolian
steppe Inner Mongolia is part of China. There

1691.44.text:
are lots of films on YouTube about locals
using golden eagles to hunt wolf and fox right

1696.01.text:
across Mongolia and into Kazakhstan. Israel
Feiler spent a few days with a falconer to

1702.09.text:
Hainan Island is located in the South China
Sea and is China's southernmost province.

1706.74.text:
The Li people, native to the island hunt python
and pig in the forests there.

1710.68.text:
Here's a home video of another of the chow-type
dogs we saw actually doing some work. This

1715.63.text:
one is catching a large rat somewhere in southern
China.

1718.32.text:
You can't cover Chinese fishing without putting
'Cormorant fishing' into the search box. This

1723.12.text:
film is a straightforward story about men
using birds to catch fish and even the BBC

1727.30.text:
can't get it too badly wrong, apart from pointing
out that the birds are 'slaves'. And what

1732.33.text: the BBC gets right is superb underwater footage.

1735.62.text:
There's quite a lot of good sea fishing in
China but not many good seafishing videos.

1740.10.text:
The more interesting film I have picked shows
electro fishing in a river. The guys here

1743.64.text:
are floating car batteries on innertubes behind
them. They fish along the bottom of the river,

1748.25.text:
electrocuting as they go. I have seen this
done elsewhere in Asia where the fishermen

1752.09.text:
save power by only electrocuting certain known
lies.

1755.42.text:
The Chinese are superbly resourceful. Here
is a news story about how they have trained

1759.19.text:
foxes to catch rats that are destroying pasture
lands. The presenter points out that foxes

1765.41.text:
Now, is there a European sporting agent operating
in China? I hear you demand. Well this Spanish

1770.90.text:
operator claims to show argali sheep hunting
in China. Chinese hunters we met told us that

1775.77.text:
North-West China and Inner Mongolia are the
two great paradises for hunters, with game

1780.26.text:
including deer, bear and wolf. They were unclear
about how legal this is. And they were vague

1784.70.text:
about the methods, mentioning everything from
knives to dogs to AK47s.

1788.88.text:
Finally, let's go back more than 100 years
to this extraordinary film from French IndoChina,

1794.01.text:
which shows buffalo hunting by white-clad
colonialists in pith helmets. This was filmed

1798.48.text:
not far (by Chinese standards) from where
I had my pheasant outing.

1801.85.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you have a YouTube film you would

1804.89.text:
like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,
send it in via YouTube, or email me the link

1811.76.text:
Well I'm on the beach for a well-earned break
after all that hard hunting, but not for long

1814.67.text:
because we are back next week and if you are
watching this on Youtube please don't hesitate

1818.52.text:
to hit the subscribe button that is somewhere
around the outside of the screen or go to

1821.89.text:
our website www.fieldsportschannel.tv where
you can click to like us on Facebook, follow

1825.32.text:
us on Twitter or scroll down to the bottom
of the page, pop your email address into our

1829.39.text:
constant contact box. There is a special incentive
this week. If you can tell me the time code

1835.59.text:
in this show where you saw my friend the panda
then you will be entered into a draw to win
